{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3414626,"name":"timTsotsali","username":"hamitHangel","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/f9ae1b/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-12T13:06:39.281Z","cooked":"

i am shooting the note like team 2056 with 3 different wheel slides on the right and the leftof the shooter , both spining in differente velocities , hiw can i determine the overall shooter velocity

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-08-12T13:06:39.281Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":128,"readers_count":127,"score":40.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":469685,"topic_slug":"help-with-shooter-calculations","display_username":"timTsotsali","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61558,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-with-shooter-calculations/469685/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3414628,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-12T13:15:03.222Z","cooked":"

Theoretically, if the gamepiece does not slip relative to the shooter wheels, the tangential velocity of the wheel is the same as the gamepiece exit velocity. Any difference in the wheel speeds imparts some energy to rotation, rather than translation.

The translational velocity will be proportional to the average of the two wheel speeds. The amount of rotation imparted is proportional to the difference between them.

In reality, there usually is at least some slip. Additionally, it’s hard to predict exactly how much the wheels will slow down when you put a load on them. Finally, even if you could precisely control the exit velocity of the gamepiece, it’s not always easy to know what velocity you need to hit a specific target (air resistance in particular will, sometimes, play a big role).

All teams I’ve seen set these things up will ultimately tune by trial and error on the final mechanism.

gerthworm:

it’s hard to predict exactly how much the wheels will slow down when you put a load on them

This is a big factor in the exit velocity. Depending on the amount of compression applied to the game piece as it’s smashed between the wheels. The more compression there is, the less slip you’ll have, but the sudden slowdown will be increased.

Trial and error with a slo-mo camera and distance chart would seem like the best method. Think like what mythbusters did with their velocity/projectile tests. If you have video showing how far linearly the object travels in 1 second, or look at the distance moved between frames and average them together you can get the true exit velocity
